repnme.cdata!:
Grenada - Emergency Recovery and Disaster
            Management Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Emergency Recovery and
            Disaster Management Project were as follows: the outcome was
            satisfactory, the sustainability was likely, the
            institutional development impact was modest, and the Bank
            and borrower performance were both satisfactory. Lessons
            learned from the project: The project has clearly
            demonstrated the economic benefits and the value of
            undertaking retrofitting and mitigation works. The Bank
            should have dealt more forcefully with the institutional
            strengthening component of the project from the start.
            Requiring that Government counterpart funds be made
            available by loan and credit effectiveness greatly
            facilitated initial project implementation. For large
            mitigation works, design and supervision contracts should
            preferably be procured on a competitive basis rather than
            under a government appointed consultant arrangement. The
            Bank needs to consider requiring performance guarantees in
            consultant contracts and applying penalties for late
            submission of expected outputs.

repnme.cdata!:
Grenada - Emergency Recovery and Disaster
            Management Project (Phase II)

abstracts.cdata!:
The Emergency Recovery and Disaster
            Management Project, Second Phase, will strengthen the
            ability to direct disaster management agencies, and enhance
            their capacity to mitigate adversity, concerning particular
            disasters such as floods, landslides, storm surges, and
            hurricanes in Grenada. The components will: 1) finance the
            National Emergency Relief Organization's strengthening,
            and, develop a country-wide early warning, and emergency
            communications system, through the implementation of shelter
            programs, and capacity building measures for the Ministry of
            Communications, Works and Public Utilities. Equipment will
            be financed, as well as comprehensive training, and public
            awareness programs to address disaster management; 2)
            implement preventive physical mitigation, responsive to
            adversities resulting from Hurricane Lenny (November 1999),
            which will include sea defenses in protection against storm
            surges; rehabilitation of exposed road sections;
            feasibility, and design of a prioritized sea defense
            investment program; drainage and flood control through
            engineering design for flood-prone areas; and, river
            training, and slope protection civil works; and, 3) finance
            project management, by appointing a Project Coordinator, an
            assistant Project Coordinator, Procurement Officer,
            Accountant, and Administrative Assistant. Office equipment,
            and technical, and financial audits will also be funded.

repnme.cdata!:
Grenada - Emergency Recovery and Disaster
            Management Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The Emergency Recovery and Disaster
            Management Project in Grenada, includes physical works in
            response to damages caused by Hurricane Lenny (November
            1999), namely rehabilitation of roads, and sea defenses in
            protection against storm surges. This environmental
            assessment focuses on the potential negative impacts of
            those works at Queens Park - Grand Mal, and Grand Roy -
            Palmist. It reviews the legal and institutional framework,
            and its weaknesses, basically under the Land Development
            Control Authority, responsible for land use management,
            although discussions also involved other government
            agencies. The key issues identified included beach
            protection and improvement; preservation of fishing sites;
            pollution control, road safety, and, public awareness.
            Although no significant negative impacts are expected,
            measures to mitigate beach and marine environment, traffic,
            and public inconveniences, include beach replenishment works
            to prevent beach erosion, and, alternative fishing methods,
            such as "ringing", should replace net fishing,
            inconvenient due to the construction of new sea defenses
            Excavation works should be limited to the dry season,
            avoiding vegetative degradation. Appropriate waste storage
            sites to avoid oil/petrol spillage, and contamination, will
            be identified for final disposal, as set by public
            standards. An environmental monitoring system should be
            established, for evaluation by relevant agencies. Traffic
            signs, and a traffic management plan will appropriately
            address road safety measures.
